ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Evolving Soft Robots with CPPNs (New Paper & Video)
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello Derek, Thanks for your comments on our work. I don t mind at all you saying that you think Sims creatures are just as natural. I m actually quite

Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Evolving Soft Robots with CPPNs (New Paper & Video)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=6LHuy5f_QNCjrIF45vDJ0BQDMWci8ze7Re4XNHjdfqQ2kR15q4In
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune


--Apple-Mail=_00148F9B-1D5D-49A1-9723-648F6B46BE1B
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello Derek,

Thanks for your comments on our work. I don't mind at all you=
 saying that you think Sims creatures are just as natural. I'm actually qui=
te interested in hearing the community's opinions on this front, whatever t=
hey are. We purposefully did not take a stand on whether we have matched/be=
at Sims. Instead, our point was simply that adding the degrees of freedom w=
e did and evolving with CPPNs shows promise that may, with future work, ena=
ble the community to produce organisms that obviously surpass Sims. I defin=
itely think we are not "obviously" better yet, which should be a goal of ou=
r field. 

Your question about why the creatures are not more regular one i=
s an interesting one that I myself have been puzzling over since the beginn=
ing of this project. I originally expected that we'd get creatures like tho=
se from EndlessForms.com that walk around. As you point out, though, the cr=
eatures in this paper are not nearly that symmetric (either bilaterally or =
radially). There is clearly a lot of regularity, especially compared to the=
 direct encoding (as Ken points out), but not nearly as much as in EndlessF=
orms and Picbreeder. My current leading hypothesis as to why is very simila=
r to Ken's, which is why our next step is to repeat the work with diversity=
 algorithms like MOLE and NS+LC (novelty search + local competition). 

As =
for when different types of symmetry evolved in nature: a lot of that is ad=
dressed in Raff's book "The Shape of Life", which Ken recommended to me lon=
g ago. 

Thanks again for your comments. I look forward to seeing your evol=
ved creature work when it comes out. 


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Assistant=
 Professor
Computer Science
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@...
jeffcl=
une.com

On Apr 14, 2013, at 11:50 AM, Derek James <djames@...> wrote=
:

> 
> On Sat, Apr 13, 2013 at 4:00 PM, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote=
:
> 
> Hi Derek, nice to see you back. I think you raise a very interesting=
 question about the degree of regularity in these creatures. Of course, I d=
on't speak for the authors but one thing I'm sure you also noticed is the c=
ompletely disorganized and amorphous directly-encoded individual in figure =
7. Compared to that, it's clear even here the CPPNs are having a significan=
t organizing effect on these overall morphologies.
> 
> 
> Yes, I noticed t=
he very disorganized phenotype that resulted from direct encoding, but is t=
he linkage between direct/indirect encodings and regularity maybe not that =
tightly coupled? Just to be clear, we're defining direct encodings as 1 gen=
e -> 1 trait, and indirect encodings as a 1 gene -> multiple traits, right?=
 In that case, you could certainly come up with direct encodings that exhib=
it a high degree of regularity, as well as indirect encodings that don't. I=
 certainly see how an indirect encoding *can* buy you more regularity, but =
whether or not that's the case seems highly dependent on the specifics of t=
he encoding. 
>  
> Nevertheless, it's still an interesting question why th=
ese creatures aren't even more regular, so I wanted to throw out a hypothes=
is: It's speculation at this point, but I would guess part of the effect se=
en here is the "objective paradox" caused by rewarding them only for walkin=
g farther. That kind of very explicit objective encourages piecewise kind o=
f improvement, i.e. if I add some idiosyncratic element to my body and it m=
akes me just a bit faster, that element will get rewarded and tacked on to =
my lineage forever. In addition, if I discover some kind of overarching reg=
ularity like bilateral symmetry, it will not be retained unless it immediat=
ely significantly improves my gait. So I'd speculate that you'd see more re=
gularity with some kind of behavioral and/or morphological diversity pressu=
re (like novelty search, novelty search with local competition, or some kin=
d of multiobjectivization like MOLE) rather than just pushing only for fast=
er and faster walkers, because diversity pressures can reward and hold onto=
 overall changes in organization even if they don't immediately lead to imp=
rovements in ambulation. Of course, the authors acknowledge this issue them=
selves in their discussion as well, so it's clearly already on their minds,=
 but certainly interesting to look at in the future.
> 
> That certainly ma=
kes sense. It raises the question of how bilateral symmetry arose in biolog=
ical organisms. Maybe this has been brought up on the list before, but is t=
here a good source to paleontology studies that estimates when bilateral sy=
mmetry arose and whether or not it might have been a result of piecewise im=
provement (i.e. gradualism) or some dramatic jump in the search space (i.e.=
 punctuated equilibrium)? Maybe this just isn't well understood. I don't kn=
ow the literature on this at all.
> 
> Also, if we're explicitly evolving w=
alkers/crawlers/swimmers is it really much of a cheat to go ahead and enfor=
ce a high degree of bilateral symmetry in the phenotypes, since we know fro=
m biological organisms all the benefits that come with it? It would seem fi=
ne to do that if our goal is just to evolve really fast, really efficient m=
overs. 
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_00148F9B-1D5D-49A1-9723-648F6B46BE1B

    <div id=3D"ygrp-text"><div><br class=3D"webkit-block-placeholder"></d=
iv><div dir=3D"ltr">On Sat, Apr 13, 2013 at 4:00 PM, Ken <span dir=3D"ltr">=

<blockquote class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"border-left:1p=
x #ccc solid;"><p>
<br>
Hi Derek, nice to see you back.  I think you raise =
a very interesting question about the degree of regularity in these creatur=
es. Of course, I don't speak for the authors but one thing I'm sure you als=
o noticed is the completely disorganized and amorphous directly-encoded ind=
ividual in figure 7.  Compared to that, it's clear even here the CPPNs are =
having a significant organizing effect on these overall morphologies.<br>

=
<br></p></blockquote><div>Yes, I noticed the very disorganized phenotype th=
at resulted from direct encoding, but is the linkage between direct/indirec=
t encodings and regularity maybe not that tightly coupled? Just to be clear=
, we're defining direct encodings as 1 gene -> 1 trait, and indirect enc=
odings as a 1 gene -> multiple traits, right? In that case, you could ce=
rtainly come up with direct encodings that exhibit a high degree of regular=
ity, as well as indirect encodings that don't. I certainly see how an indir=
ect encoding *can* buy you more regularity, but whether or not that's the c=
ase seems highly dependent on the specifics of the encoding. </div>
<d=
iv> </div><blockquote class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"border-left:1px #=
ccc solid;"><p>
Nevertheless, it's still an interesting question why these =
creatures aren't even more regular, so I wanted to throw out a hypothesis: =
 It's speculation at this point, but I would guess part of the effect seen =
here is the "objective paradox" caused by rewarding them only for walking f=
arther.  That kind of very explicit objective encourages piecewise kind of =
improvement, i.e. if I add some idiosyncratic element to my body and it mak=
es me just a bit faster, that element will get rewarded and tacked on to my=
 lineage forever.  In addition, if I discover some kind of overarching regu=
larity like bilateral symmetry, it will not be retained unless it immediate=
ly significantly improves my gait.   So I'd speculate that you'd see more r=
egularity with some kind of behavioral and/or morphological diversity press=
ure (like novelty search, novelty search with local competition, or some ki=
nd of multiobjectivization like MOLE) rather than just pushing only for fas=
ter and faster walkers, because diversity pressures can reward and hold ont=
o overall changes in organization even if they don't immediately lead to im=
provements in ambulation.  Of course, the authors acknowledge this issue th=
emselves in their discussion as well, so it's clearly already on their mind=
s, but certainly interesting to look at in the future.</p>
</blockquote><di=
v>That certainly makes sense. It raises the question of how bilateral symme=
try arose in biological organisms. Maybe this has been brought up on the li=
st before, but is there a good source to paleontology studies that estimate=
s when bilateral symmetry arose and whether or not it might have been a res=
ult of piecewise improvement (i.e. gradualism) or some dramatic jump in the=
 search space (i.e. punctuated equilibrium)? Maybe this just isn't well und=
erstood. I don't know the literature on this at all.</div>
<div><br></div><=
div>Also, if we're explicitly evolving walkers/crawlers/swimmers is it real=
ly much of a cheat to go ahead and enforce a high degree of bilateral symme=
try in the phenotypes, since we know from biological organisms all the bene=
fits that come with it? It would seem fine to do that if our goal is just t=
o evolve really fast, really efficient movers. </div>
</div></div></di=
v><div><br class=3D"webkit-block-placeholder"></div>

    </div>
